in fact almost two-thirds of Windows instances running on the public cloud are running on AWS and really that's

of running Windows applications is operating the file storage for those applications and probably something that
that most folks in this room can relate to is that managing Windows File servers on Prem is a pretty big challenge and it
there's really kind of two big things that you need to worry about and think about when you're managing your Windows
file servers so the first is managing the hardware so everything from planning capacity to procuring and purchasing the
hardware often with long lead times setting up storage servers and volumes detecting and addressing hardware
failures and make it capex investments and then there's a software part so
installing and configuring server software setting up and configuring the file system and the file serving

gets significantly easier if you're running those windows file servers on the cloud but and that's because the

need to manage the underlying hardware but you still need to manage the software and so customers have been
telling us that they don't want to manage the hardware or the software and that's what we set up to solve for
customers with fsx and so our
overarching goal for fsx for Windows file server was to deliver the best solution for the lift and shift of your
Windows storage to the cloud and that really meant three things the first is
100% Windows application compatibility Windows applications are written for and
they're tested against NTFS file systems with all of the unique semantics an idiot' secrecies that that that file
system provides and you want 100% compatibility with it so you don't want
to be figuring out why your application isn't working in strange ways or in edge cases you just want it to work
and you want it to work with a native Windows file system too lots of Windows
applications work with with small files so they work with small files and they work with a lot of metadata and what
that generally means is that they're they're pretty latency sensitive because if you're doing a lot of operations with
a lot of small files especially if you're doing them kind of in serial the latencies of of the overhead of opening
each of these files are working with each of these files adds up and you notice significant performance
implications if the latency isn't really where it needs to be for the underlying file storage layer so for us
sub-millisecond latency x' were super important for this offering at the same
time high throughput and high ops also really important that's just table stakes for any type of network file
storage and then we wanted to provide customers with flexibility based on workload needs so what that specifically
means is the ability to tune the throughput level independent of storage so you can really kind of right size your throughput for your workload and
then we wanted it to be enterprise ready and what that really means is highly available highly durable secure and and
meets compliances and why do those things matter why do those three things
matter well the native compatibility and the strong performance means that it will just work your applications you'll be
able to lift and shift because you'll be able to lift and shift your file storage and things will just work and the the
security the compliance is the availability that durability means that you can use it for a broad spectrum of
applications with sensitive data with different enterprise requirements etc so
really we wanted this to be a robust offering as well from that perspective
and so when we first set out to meet these goals we looked at just
implementing the SMB protocol on a non native Windows file system and a lot of
vendors a lot of providers do that and we realized that that just wouldn't deliver the right experience for customers and that's because the file
system matters and you can't just tack the SMB protocol on to any file system so for real
Windows file system compatibility you really want to have a file system that's
built from the ground up to work with Windows and it's not just the native compatibility as the performance as well a file system that's really optimized
for Windows type of types of workloads and so the other thing that we looked at
was okay we could actually build a Windows file system from the ground up so really something that's completely
optimized to be a Windows file system and we took a long hard look at doing that as well and we realized customers they really

directly leasing and fine leasing to help your clients be able to cache the

Amazon fsx for Windows file server file system provides something called a throughput capacity which is the speed

capacity when you create a file system the throughput capacity itself can range

24/7 throughput that you can drive on your file system what we observed was file based workloads generally tend to
be very spiky in nature meaning that there's there tends to be highly intense periods of you know very high i/o
activity and then plenty of time in between where your file system tends to be idle though so to support these kinds
of spiky workload needs what we do is we allow you to burst to much higher levels
of throughput at each of these to put capacity levels or for the smaller throughput capacity levels and what this
allows you to do is burst for at least 30 minutes a day to these much higher speeds for example even with 8 megabytes per

then even further the file server that we manage for you we actually support
